awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: EiR: Understanding Interactions of Gold and Silver Nanoparticles with Proteins to Achieve Optimum Surface Plasmon Effect
awd_abstract_narration:
A variety of diseases are identified by protein markers. Nano-sized particles using metals such as gold and silver possess unique electronic and optical properties, which can be significantly altered when effected by an external cue, such as the interaction with a specific protein. Developing a fundamental understanding of nanoparticle-protein interactions and their associated optical properties is critical for the development of novel detection devices with high sensitivity and selectivity for detection of diseases, such as cancer and Alzheimer's. The knowledge obtained from this proposed research on nanoparticle-protein interactions will further assist in the development of novel technologies for the biomedical, materials, and energy sectors. This project connects researchers and resources at Howard University and Winston-Salem State University to integrate education and research training for students at the undergraduate and graduate levels. The project will provide rigorous training opportunities for the next generation of African-American and other students from underrepresented groups pursuing careers in Chemistry, Chemical Engineering, Physics and Mechanical Engineering. Results from the current and developing research on the nanoparticle-protein interactions, bio-simulations and biosensor design will be incorporated into workshops and classes, to expand the interests and experience of under-represented students in the STEM fields. This will promote successful academic and career paths.

Understanding the fundamental plasmonic response of gold and silver nanoparticles interacting with proteins is critical for molecular detection. This includes understanding the electronic properties and electromagnetic spectrum of discrete uniform gold and silver nanoparticles. This also includes understanding nanoparticle interactions with protein markers in a biochemical environment. The interactions of interest include physical and chemical coordination of the nanoparticles to the protein and the electromagnetic and plasmonic response from protein-nanoparticle interactions. The project will be achieved by coupling experimental spectroscopy with computational simulations at multiple scales (quantum, atomistic, molecular and continuum). The proposed study aims to elucidate different factors, including proteins' packing structure based on nanoparticles varying in type, shape, and means of surface functionalization. These fundamental nanoparticle-protein interactions will determine the plasmonic effect on electromagnetic and plasmonic signals. Simulations at the microscopic and macroscopic levels will provide knowledge on both the physical interactions and chemical reactions of nanoparticles and proteins, which are crucial for correlating nanoparticles' optic signals following environmental responses. Moreover, chemically modified nanoparticles' electronic structure, optical spectra, and magnetic properties will be studied using local surface plasmon resonance spectrum or surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy. These experimental results will be validated with quantum simulations. Subsequently, theoretical studies will more clearly explain spectrum signals and lead to improved experimental design of the target sensor. The multidisciplinary research team consists of experts in quantum and atomistic simulations, bio-nano interface, protein folding, experimental optical sensor design, and nanoparticle synthesis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was part of a joint collaborative research effort between Howard University (HU, NSF Award # 1831559) and Winston-Salem State University (WSSU, this project - NSF Award # 1831548), with a shared title “Collaborative Proposal: EiR: Understanding Interactions of Gold and Silver Nanoparticles with Proteins to Achieve Optimum Surface Plasmon Effect”. The major goals of the project are to understand the fundamental plasmonic response of gold and silver nanoparticles (NPs) interacting with proteins, and to involve undergraduate students in STEM research.  

The initial project duration was 9/2018 – 8/2021. Two one-year extensions were granted by NSF at the primary investigator’s (PI’s) request (with no additional costs to NSF) due to the Covid-caused delays. The project was officially finalized by the end of August 2023. 

In the first half of the five-year duration of the project, the interdisciplinary team at HU and WSSU worked to employ mesoscopic coarse-grained simulations to study coronas of two different proteins formed on gold NPs. The exposure of NPs to biofluids, such as water with proteins, leads to the rapid coverage of proteins on NPs and these structures are called protein coronas. The corona structure was found to be dependent on protein types and the size of nanoparticles. Protein coronas alter the NP surface chemicophysical properties and affect their performance in applications. The fundamental study of protein corona on bare gold nanoparticles will shed light on the future development of nanoparticle-based molecular sensing techniques of SERS and drug delivery. The findings were published as an article in ACS journal Langmuir titled “Protein Corona on Gold Nanoparticles Studied with Coarse-Grained Simulations” in 2020 (DOI: 10.1021/acs.langmuir.0c02767). 

In the second half of the project duration, the investigators continued their studies of nanoparticle-protein interactions. This time they focused on protein corona formation on silver nanoparticles, and they utilized multiscale simulations to examine the NPs’ size and surface hydrophilicity effects on formation dynamics and the structure of the protein coronas. The formation of the protein corona on NPs affects their surface properties and applications. Fundamental studies using computer simulations in this perspective at the molecular level can complement general experimental studies, are critical to widen NP applications in drug delivery, nanotechnology, nanomedicine, biosensors, biocompatible materials, marine vessels' antifouling coating, biofuel cells, etc., and are essential for theoretical modeling development. Additionally, the team’s electromagnetic computation is critical to biosensing device development. The new findings were published as an article in the Journal of Physical Chemistry B in 2022 (DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcb.1c08267). 

In the duration of the project, each year, on average, four underrepresented students at WSSU were involved in the project research year-round, and many more at HU. At WSSU, they were trained on computational physics and chemistry research skills, such as Unix command and vi editor usage, remote supercomputer access and usage, using the Quantum Espresso package to do materials modeling at the nanoscale, etc. From 2019-2021, three years in a roll, the collaborative team organized an annual summer workshop for minority students at HU and WSSU to provide research training and educational experiences. The first was in-person at HU, the latter two online due to Covid-19 restrictions. The workshops had a total of about 44 student attendees and were well received. The topics of the hands-on workshops included nanoscience technologies, surface science, biosensing, quantum and atomistic simulation and high-performance computing on high-performance supercomputers. The invited speakers at the workshops came from a wide range of institutions and national laboratories around the country, such as Haverford College, University of Michigan, University of North Dakota, University of Southern California, Cal State Long Beach, NC A&T, BNL, NASA JPL and ORNL. Many project participants have benefited from their research experience and have received or are seeking admission to graduate schools. Two WSSU participants are now dedicated chemistry graduate students, and another WSSU participant is actively seeking graduate admission in Fall 2023. The impact of the project on our underrepresented students is demonstrated to be positive and profound.
